len by my first wife and she been dead 'bout 70

nd I up

holes just a-sha

Songs & Music.name: Hagar Lewis

loose Miss Mary was training me and sister to do

When I git dat fever, my missy told me n

th some
others. We is slippin' 'long quiet like and a paddle roller jump out

s to death with oxen.
For stealin' or somethin'. I can't say we were treated bad, 'cause I'd
tell a story. I've always been treated good by whites, but many of the
niggers was killed. They'd say bad words

"We works every day 'cept Sunday and has to do our washin' den. Does

comes in at night we has to go right to bed

in' in oil wells now. Washington Lewis,

ere. De white folks say to sign de

ap of 'em! I couldn't count 'em. My daddy run

"Dey went to my dad

Ghost Stories.name: ISOM ROBERTS

' happened. It most makes
me tremble to talk to you 'bout it now. Providence, or some kind of

Ghost Stories.name: ISOM ROBERTS
Ghost Stories.snippet:
all of them befo' de Yankees
set them free and that they wouldn't need no money after they was done
dead. All de slaves was mighty sad and troubled, all dat day, when old
marster made dat speech to them.

Ghost Stories.name: ISOM ROBERTS
Ghost Stories.snippet:
a plenty of
persons dat has lost deir heads by not lettin' deir tongues rest.
Marster Sam Louie is dead now. He can't disturb nobody in his grave. He

Ghost Stories.snippet:
man I would have for a wife, 'cause
I ain't gwine to find no woman Lucy's equal. All my chillun are dead,

=Stiles M. Scruggs=
 =Columbia, S.C.=


=_THE POT OF GOLD._=




Martha Richardson, who tells this story, lives at 924 Senate Street,
Columbia, S.C. Her father was an Indian and her mother a mulatto. She

Stories & Tales.name: MARY RAINES
Stories & Tales.snippet:
pt it and we all work on just de same and she buy these two
lots on Senate Street. She build de two-story house here at 924, where
you sittin' now, and de cottage nex' door. She always had rent money
comin

Stories & Tales.name: MARY RAINES

y: 'Ain't her a good one? Must weigh
ten pounds. I's gwine to name dis baby for your mama, William. Tell her
I name her, Mary, for her, but I 'spects some folks'll call her 'Polly',

d for many

uch 'skimpin', to make ends meet at home, as we go

ys holiday or
